3 Power-over-CoaXPress

The microEnable 5 CoaXPress Series frame grabber support basically Power-over-CoaXPress cameras, since Power-Over-CoaXPress (PoCXP) is a mandatory feature of the CoaXPress standard.

The microEnable 5 CoaXPress Series frame grabber frame grabber has a special connector (4pin Molex) at the rear end that has necessarily to be connected to provide frame grabber power and PoCXP at the BNC connectors. This connector can be connected to a standard Molex 4pin power connector of a PC power supply.



4 CoaXPress Ports




DIN 1.0/2.3 Ports 1 - 4

33 Presence Detect VCCIO (+3.3V) 34

 Plug assignment of the trigger plug (34 pin flat cable).

Default I/O configuration: 3.3V logic level signals (LVCMOS33). Signals are driven by open-collector drivers, pullups are on-board.


Please refer to the sections Opto Trigger for microEnable IV and TTL Trigger, respectively, to learn how trigger extension boards are connected and used. Please refer to the specific Applet documentation to learn how the trigger signals can be used.



6 LED Description

LEDs on the Slot Bracket

There are LEDs mounted on the slot bracked of the mE5 CXP frame grabbers.

On-Board LEDs

There are eight LEDs mounted on the mE5 CXP frame grabbers.Some LEDs have fixed functions, others are programmable (software/firmware).

Functions of the LEDs (from left to right):

1) FPGA Configuration DONE

If the "DONE" LED is on, the frame grabber is ready for operation:

  • The FPGA on the frame grabber has been configured successfully.
  • The frame grabber identifies itself as a PCIe board and is recognized by the PC.
  • Under Windows, it is detected by the Device Manager.

2) Applet Specific LED1

3) Applet Specific LED2

4) Applet Specific LED3

5) Applet Specific LED4

6) Power Good

7) 12V Power On

8) 12V Power for PoCXP On


7 Important Note Regarding PCIe Bus Data Through-Put

The PCIe bus data throughput depends on the motherboard, the chip set and the BIOS configuration of the PC and can differ from slot to slot. It can also depend on the number of installed PCIe-boards. For example, a PCIe x8 slot may support only x4 performance.

Always check the mainboard manual thoroughly to be sure.
